citation.article-title: Desulfobulbus rhabdoformis sp. nov., a sulfate reducer from a water-oil separation system.

p.s: Description of Desulfobulbus rhabdoformis sp. nov.
Desulfobulbus rhabdoformis (rhabd.o.for'mis. Gr. fem. n. rhabdos rod; L. adj. suffix -formis-like, of the shape of; rhaboformis rod-shaped)
Cells are non-motile, straight to slightly curved rods with rounded ends, 0.6-1.0 by 1.7-3.5 μm, appearing singly, in pairs or in chains with ceIls of various size.
Strictly anaerobic, metabolism respiratory and/or fermentative.
Sulfate, sulfite and thiosulfate serve as electron acceptors.
With sulfate as electron acceptor, electron donors are propionate, lactate, pyruvate, ethanol, propanol, malate, fumarate and H2+2 mM acetate.
Acetate is formed as the end product of incomplete oxidation.
Fermentative growth on lactate, pyruvate, malate and fumarate.
Vitamins are not required, and growth occurs optimally with 1.5-2.0 % NaCl and 0.1-0.3% (w/v) MgCl2. 6H2O in the medium.
The temperature range for growth is 10- 40 OC, the optimum is 31°C.
Desulforubidin, cytochromes c and b, and menaquinone-5(H2) are present.
The DNA base composition is 50.6 mol% G + C.
Isolated from an water-oil separation system on a North sea oil-production platform.
